page.paragraph: Now listen to a conversation between two students.
Hi, John.
Hi, Cathy.
What's up, John? You look worried.
Oh, I'm not worried, Cathy. I just have a big decision to make, and I'm not sure what to do. I'm confused, not worried.
Anything I can help with?
It's about my schedule for next semester.
You haven't finished with your schedule for next semester yet? Schedules are due by the end of the day today. But I'm sure you know that.
I do, and I have just one more decision to make before I turn my schedule in. Maybe you can help me with this decision.
What are you trying to decide?
I need to figure out how many courses to take.
That should be an easy decision. A full-time schedule is four courses. Are you thinking of taking only a part-time schedule, maybe two or three courses?
No, it's not that. I'm thinking that maybe I should take five courses instead of four.

Five courses? But four courses is a full-time schedule. You want to take more than a full-time schedule? That would be a whole lot of work. For me, well, I couldn't handle more than four courses. Say, why are you thinking of taking five courses?
I'm thinking that if I take an extra course each semester, I can graduate early.
But that means you'll have to spend all your time studying, and you wouldn't be able to do anything else. Tell me, how are you doing this semester? You're taking four courses now, aren't you?
Yes, I'm taking four courses, and I'm doing OK.
You're doing just OK in four classes? Not well?
Just OK.
If you're not doing really well in four courses, do you really want to try five courses?
